org.latency4j.util

Class Latency4JEmailSender

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.latency4j.util.Latency4JEmailSender

  • public class Latency4JEmailSender
extends java.lang.Object

    Utility class for packaging and sending email via the Java Mail API.

    Note that this class provides a 1-shot approach to sending a single email. An instance should either be reset by calling the reset() method or discarded once the sendMail() method has been invoked. Prior to such an invocation however, the message state can be altered by invoking any of the message mutators.

    Put differently, instances of this class maintain conversational state, which has to be reset after each message is sent.

    Please note that this class is not thread-safe.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Latency4JEmailSender

        public Latency4JEmailSender(javax.mail.Session mailSession)

        Constructs an instance which builds and sends messages in HTML format. Note that even when HTML format is used, a fallback text representation is always included as part of the message. This ensures that clients unable to show HTML can still display the message.

        Parameters:
        mailSession - The Session via which the message will be sent.

      • Latency4JEmailSender

        public Latency4JEmailSender(javax.mail.Session mailSession,
                            boolean sendInHTMLFormat)

        Constructor which provides a means of turning off the default HTML format. This is in contrast to Latency4JEmailSender(Session), which results in the instance formatting all messages as HTML.

        Parameters:
        mailSession - The Session for which the message is being constructed, and via which the message will be sent.
        sendInHTMLFormat - A value of True is equivalent to invoking the constructor Latency4JEmailSender(Session) instead, and a value of False will result in all messages being sent as plain text.
        See Also:
        Latency4JEmailSender(Session)

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        public void reset()

        Resets an instance's conversational state. Where a single instance of this type is re-used multiple times to send several emails, then this method must be called after each invocation of the sendMail() method. It, in effect, allows the caller to begin creating another email anew.

      • setSubject

        public void setSubject(java.lang.String subject)

        Specifies the subject of the message to be sent.

        Parameters:
        subject - The email's subject.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail Session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • setFrom

        public void setFrom(java.lang.String address)

        Specifies the address from which the email is to be sent. Note that this does not necessarily have to be consistent with the Session; it is simply the value to which the "From" field of the email will be set. This also means that it will serve as the default 'reply-to' address.

        Parameters:
        address - The value of the 'From' email field.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail Session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.
        See Also:
        setReplyTo(String)

      • setReplyTo

        public void setReplyTo(java.lang.String address)

        Sets the address to which replies to this message will be directed. This is simply the address to which the "Reply-To" field of the message will be set. Where not specified, this will default to the "From" address as specified via the setFrom(String).

        Parameters:
        address - The address to which replies to the message will be directed.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail Session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.
        See Also:
        setFrom(String)

      • setText

        public void setText(java.lang.String... messageText)

        Specifies the text of the email. The text can be supplied as a single string or a list of strings.

        If the text is specified as a multi-element array, each element is treated as a separate paragraph. Thus, where the email format is HTML, the elements are enclosed with HTML <p> tags. In the plain-text equivalent, the elements are simply separated by newline characters.

        Parameters:
        messageText - The message text, specified as a variable length string array.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • setText

        public void setText(java.util.List<java.lang.String> paragraphs)

        Specifies the text of the email. This method is equivalent to setText(String...), except for the use of a List for specifying the message paragraphs.

        Parameters:
        paragraphs - The message text, specified as a List.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • sendMail

        public void sendMail()

        Sends the underlying message being packaged by this instance. Put differently, it sends the message which represents the conversation state, to date, of the instance. An invocation of this method thus marks the end of the conversation between an instance of this class and its callers. Any subsequent invocation of the message construction methods will result in an exception. However, the reset() method can be used to reset the conversational state of the instance again thus allowing for the creation of a new message.

        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if this method has already been invoked on this instance and the reset() method has not been used to reset the conversational state.
        See Also:
        reset()

      • addAttachment

        public void addAttachment(java.io.File dataFile)

        Attaches a file to the email. This method is equivalent to reading the file data into a byte array and invoking the addAttachment(String, byte[]) method, with the filename used as the attachment name.

        Parameters:
        dataFile - The file to be attached to the email.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session; if the {sendMail() has already been invoked; or if unable to read the specified file.
        See Also:
        addAttachment(String, byte[]), addAttachment(String, String), EmailDataSource

      • addAttachment

        public void addAttachment(java.lang.String attachmentName,
                          java.lang.String attachmentText)

        Creates an attachment to the email from the specified text. Note that this method is equivalent to invoking the addAttachment(String, byte[]) where the second argument is obtained by invoking the String.getBytes() method on the attachment text.

        Parameters:
        attachmentName - The name to assign to the attachment. This is typically used by the mail client as the identifier for the attachment.
        attachmentText - The text from which to create the email attachment.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.
        See Also:
        EmailDataSource, addAttachment(File), addAttachment(String, byte[])

      • addAttachment

        public void addAttachment(java.lang.String attachmentName,
                          byte[] data)

        Creates an email attachment from native data. This method is agnostic regarding the type of data content in the code>byte array. Typical uses for this method would be the attachment of documents, images, audio and files e.t.c as plain byte data.

        Parameters:
        attachmentName - The name to be applied to the attachment. This is typically used by mail client as the identifier for the attachment.
        data - The attachment data.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the {sendMail() has already been invoked.
        See Also:
        EmailDataSource, addAttachment(File), addAttachment(String, byte[])

      • addressTo

        public void addressTo(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> emailAddresses)

        Specifies a Collection of addresses to which the email should be primarily addressed. The values in the Collection will be added to the 'To:' recipient list of the email.

        Parameters:
        emailAddresses - A Collection of email addresses to which the email is to be addressed.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • addressTo

        public void addressTo(java.lang.String emailAddress)

        Provides an address to which the email should be sent. The argument value will be used to populate the 'To:' field of the mail message. This is a convenience method for scenarios where the email is intended for a single recipient only.

        Parameters:
        emailAddress - The recipient email address.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • ccTo

        public void ccTo(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> emailAddresses)

        Specifies a Collection of addresses to which the email should be copied. The values in the Collection will be used to populate the 'Cc:' recipient list of the email.

        Parameters:
        emailAddresses - A Collection of email address to which the email is to be copied.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the sendMail() has already been invoked.

      • bccTo

        public void bccTo(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> emailAddresses)
        Specifies addresses to which the email should be blind copied. The values in the address Collection will be used to populate the 'Bcc:' recipient list of the email.
        Parameters:
        emailAddresses - A Collection of email address to which the email is to be blind copied.
        Throws:
        Latency4JException - If an error occurs communicating with the mail session, or if the sendMail() has already been invoked.
